conclusion: Determine the change in the range of light incident on the central point at the bottom of the light-transmitting hole after embedding the glass brick.
The light hole is circular with a diameter L = 40 cm.
The radius r of the hole is r = L/2 = 20 cm.
The thickness of the roof (and the glass brick) is d = 20√3 cm.
The angle of incidence θ1 can be found using the tangent function: tan(θ1) = r/d = 1/√3, therefore θ1 = 30°.
The refractive index of the glass brick is n = √3.
Using Snell's Law: n1 sin(θ1) = n2 sin(θ2), where n1 = 1 (air) and n2 = √3 (glass).
Substituting the known values: 1 * sin(30°) = √3 * sin(θ2), therefore sin(θ2) = √3/6.
The new angle of incidence θ2 is approximately 15°.
The initial range of light was 30°. The new range of light is 15°. The change in the range of light is Δθ = 30° - 15° = 15°.
The range of light incident on the central point at the bottom of the light-transmitting hole is increased by 15° compared to before embedding the glass brick.
